stem: After reviewing the fetal heart rate tracing and the provided documentation, categorize each deceleration pattern with its most likely cause.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
14:00: SBAR for patient Jane Doe, G1P0, at 39 weeks gestation. Presenting complaint: decreased fetal movement reported by patient this morning. 

14:05: Assessment reveals contractions every 3-4 minutes, lasting 60-70 seconds. Cervical exam: 4 cm dilated, 70% effaced, vertex at -2 station. Fetal heart rate (FHR) baseline is 135 bpm with moderate variability. 

14:10: Noted a deceleration in FHR that mirrors the contraction pattern, with the FHR returning to baseline by the end of the contraction. 

14:25: Another contraction noted, this time with a sharp drop in FHR to 90 bpm lasting approximately 45 seconds. The deceleration did not consistently occur with contractions. Patient repositioned to left lateral position. 

14:40: FHR now demonstrates a decrease in rate to 110 bpm approximately 30 seconds after the peak of the contraction. The FHR baseline variability remains moderate.

14:50: Physician notified of FHR changes. Orders received and implemented per physician order sheet.

15:00: Continuous fetal monitoring continues. Patient tolerating labor well, reporting pain level of 6/10. Encouraging breathing techniques.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content:
14:00: BP 120/80 mmHg, HR 88 bpm, RR 18, SpO2 99%, Temp 98.8°F
14:25: BP 125/82 mmHg, HR 92 bpm, RR 20, SpO2 99%, Temp 98.9°F
14:40: BP 130/85 mmHg, HR 96 bpm, RR 22, SpO2 98%, Temp 99.0°F
Fetal Heart Rate Data:
14:00: Baseline 135 bpm, Variability: Moderate
14:10: Early Deceleration noted, FHR drops to 125 bpm
14:25: Variable Deceleration noted, FHR drops to 90 bpm
14:40: Late Deceleration noted, FHR drops to 110 bpm

tabs.title: Lab Results
tabs.content:
CBC:
Hemoglobin: 12.5 g/dL (12-16 g/dL)
Hematocrit: 37.5% (36-48%)
Platelets: 250,000/uL (150,000-400,000/uL)
WBC: 8,500/uL (4,500-11,000/uL)

Urinalysis: 
Protein: Trace
Glucose: Negative
Ketones: Negative

Group B Streptococcus: Positive

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
General: Patient appears anxious but cooperative, alert and oriented x3.
Cardiovascular: Regular heart rate and rhythm. No murmurs auscultated.
Respiratory: Clear breath sounds bilaterally.
Abdomen: Fundal height consistent with gestational age. Contractions palpable.
Fetal Assessment: Fetal heart tones auscultated. See fetal monitoring strip for details.
Cervical Exam: 4 cm dilated, 70% effaced, vertex at -2 station.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
- Continuous fetal heart rate monitoring.
- Maternal vital sign monitoring every 30 minutes.
- Reposition patient to left lateral position.
- Administer oxygen at 8 L/min via face mask if FHR abnormalities persist.
- Notify physician of any significant changes in fetal heart rate or maternal condition.
- Prepare for potential amnioinfusion if ordered by physician.
- Prepare for potential delivery based on fetal status and labor progress.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
Oxygen: 8 L/min via face mask PRN for fetal heart rate decelerations.
IV Fluids: Lactated Ringers 125 mL/hr continuous.

rationale.correct: Early decelerations are caused by fetal head compression, which stimulates the vagal nerve, resulting in a transient decrease in FHR. Late decelerations are typically caused by uteroplacental insufficiency, leading to decreased oxygen delivery to the fetus. Variable decelerations are often caused by umbilical cord compression, which reduces fetal oxygenation.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect choices would include associating deceleration patterns with incorrect underlying causes. For example, assigning early decelerations to placental insufficiency or cord compression, or late decelerations to head or cord compression.

answerBreakdown.rationale: The nurse's note at 14:10 describes a deceleration mirroring the contraction, indicating head compression as the likely cause.
The nurse's note at 14:40 describes a deceleration occurring after the peak of the contraction, suggesting placental insufficiency as the underlying cause.
The nurse's note at 14:25 describes a sharp, unpredictable drop in FHR not consistently related to contractions, with repositioning attempted, which is indicative of cord compression.

clinicalPearls: Remember the mnemonic VEAL CHOP: Variable decelerations = Cord compression; Early decelerations = Head compression; Accelerations = Okay; Late decelerations = Placental insufficiency.
Repositioning the mother is a key initial intervention for variable decelerations, as it can relieve cord compression.
Late decelerations require prompt intervention to improve placental perfusion, such as administering oxygen and IV fluids.

questionTrap.trap: Students often confuse late and variable decelerations due to their similar appearance on the FHR strip.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully assess the timing of the deceleration in relation to the contraction. Late decelerations occur after the peak of the contraction, while variable decelerations have no consistent relationship to contractions.

mnemonic.title: VEAL CHOP
mnemonic.expansion: Variable decelerations = Cord compression; Early decelerations = Head compression; Accelerations = Okay; Late decelerations = Placental insufficiency
